newsitem.title: USA: US Senators urge Clinton to back off on de minimis.
newsitem.headline: US Senators urge Clinton to back off on de minimis.

text.p: As the battle over repealing the "de minimis" exemption escalates, 18 U.S. Senators on Friday urged the Clinton Administration to back off of its endorsement of the roll back.

"Although intended to target corporations, this measure could actually punish state and local governments and limit their abillity to raise capital in the tax-exempt market," the senators warned in a two-page letter to Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin.
The Clinton Administration earlier this year called for repeal of the rule.
The House Ways and Means Committee early Friday approved a broad tax plan that would scale back considerably the de minimis exemption.

The Senate Finance Committee, meanwhile, is expected to begin voting on a tax package June 19. Panel Chairman William Roth, R-Del., has not stated publicly whether a preliminary bill will seek de minimis rule repeal.
Among the bipartisan group of senators signing Friday's letter were Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y.; Orrin Hatch, R-Utah; Christopher Dodd, D-Conn.; and Max Baucus, D-Montana.
